# 
## 
### 
#### 1. Import csv data and adding header row

```{r}
Typical_Employee_Survey_Data <-read.csv("~/Desktop/RBS/Business Forcasting/Typical_Employee_Survey_Data.csv", header=FALSE)
colnames(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data) <- c("V1", "V2", "V3", "V4", "V5", "V6", "V7", "V8", "V9", "V10", "V11")
```
#
##
###
#### 2. 5-point summary and boxplot for each column

```{r}
#summary for each column
summary(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data)
```

```{r}
#boxplot for numerical columns
boxplot(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$V5)
```

#### 3. Convert the columns that need to be converted to Factors

```{r}
Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$V5 <- as.factor(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$V5)
```



#### 4. Plot right visual for each column

```{r}
boxplot(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$V1, main="Barplot for V1")
hist(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$V2, main="Barplot for V2")
hist(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$V3, main="Barplot for V3")
hist(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$V4, main="Barplot for V4")
boxplot(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$V5, main="Barplot for V5")
hist(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$V6, main="Barplot for V6")
hist(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$V7, main="Barplot for V7")
hist(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$V8, main="Barplot for V8")
hist(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$V9, main="Barplot for V9")
hist(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$V10, main="Barplot for V10")
hist(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$V11, main="Barplot for V11")
```

#### 5. Plot scatter plots to show few relationships

```{r}
#plotting column V1 and V5
plot(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$V1,Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$V5,main = "Scatter Plot of V1 vs V5",xlab = "V1",ylab = "V5",pch=19,col="blue")
```


```{r}
#plotting column V3 and V6
plot(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$V2, Typical_Employee_Survey_Data$V6, main = "Scatter plot of V3 vs V6",xlab = "V6", ylab = "V3", pch = 19, col= "green")
```


```{r}
#plotting multiple columns
pairs(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data[, c("V1", "V5", "V6", "V3")], 
      main = "Scatter Plot Matrix",
      pch = 19, col = "red")
```
